results.title: Haitians Investigating President’s Death, Under Threat, Go Into Hiding
results.abstract: The officials, two court clerks and an investigative judge who collected evidence in President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination, are now in hiding.

results.title: Where a Vast Global Vaccination Program Went Wrong
results.abstract: After months of struggle, the U.N.-backed Covax alliance will soon have many more doses, promising relief for vaccine shortages in poorer countries. But it faces a deepening crisis: difficulties getting shots into arms as the Delta variant spreads.
results.byline: By Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins

multimedia.caption: Carrying a box of vaccines this spring in Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The country received 1.7 million AstraZeneca doses through Covax in March, but distribution is another challenge.

results.title: Queen Guitarist’s Flooded London Basement Foretells a Climate Under Pressure
results.abstract: After a heat wave and two Southeast Asia-style rainstorms that flooded the capital’s streets, subways and Brian May’s cellar, it seems timely to ask if the city is prepared to deal with wild weather.

results.title: With #MeToo Case, China Takes a Swipe at Celebrity Obsession
results.abstract: The detention of Kris Wu, a popular Canadian singer, has been hailed as a rare victory for the movement. But Beijing, wary of social activism, has cast it as a warning to celebrities.
results.byline: By Amy Qin and Elsie Chen

multimedia.caption: The performer Kris Wu at a movie premiere in Los Angeles in 2017. He has become perhaps the most prominent figure in China to be detained over #MeToo allegations.

results.title: In addition to Covid, more children are getting a respiratory virus more commonly seen in winter.
results.abstract: An outbreak of respiratory syncytial virus, combined with growing Covid-19 pediatric cases, is straining hospital resources in some U.S. cities.

multimedia.caption: A student in New York last month. Rising cases of Covid-19 and respiratory syncytial virus are straining pediatric resources in parts of the United States.
multimedia.copyright: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
